awd_titl_txt: Toward Increasing the Impact of Grand Innovation Prizes: Lessons from the Emergence of an Autonomous Vehicle Innovation Ecosystem
awd_abstract_narration:
Innovation prizes have become an important tool for federal agencies to improve the impact of public investments in research and development. For example, the recent emergence of autonomous vehicles (AVs) are attributed to the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) grand challenge competitions (2004-2007). However, there is little understanding of why and how innovation prizes function to improve technology, education, and commercial outcomes associated with research and development. This project thus seeks to understand the specific elements responsible for innovation prize impact. Understanding how and why technological, educational, and commercial impact occurred will not only contribute to the prize model literature, it will also generate insights important to the establishment and effective management of innovation prizes, improving the social and commercial impact of future innovation prize competitions. 

To fulfill the project goals, the research team will implement an embedded, multiple case study design, an approach well-suited for investigating complex, interconnected phenomena over time, at different levels of analysis. The study team will conduct case studies through focused interviews individuals from universities, government agencies, companies, and other organizations involved in AV development that participated in the DARPA grand challenge competitions. The study will also include case studies of similar organizations involved in AV development that did not participate in the grand challenges. These case studies will generate both primary and rival theoretical explanations of AV development and impact and, through comparison among cases, illuminate how and why innovation prize impact occurred. In the addition to publication, project findings will be disseminated in a workshop focused on the utility of grand challenge models for improving STEM education and entrepreneurship outcomes among minorities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Our proposal initially focused on understanding the impact of the 2004-2007 DARPA Grand Challenges (DGCs). DARPA, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agencies, is recognized for its role in seeding important innovations in society, such as the internet, stealth technology, and robotics. DARPA’s 2004-2007 Grand Challenges, three competitions in which disparate teams built autonomous vehicles to complete objectives, is credited with the recent emergence of an autonomous vehicle (AV) industry. Our research project therefore sought to understand why and how this occurred.

Our initial understanding of DGC impact was informed by books and other popular media that documented the important role of “titan teams”, especially Carnegie Mellon University and Stanford University, both well-resourced universities that have received significant funding from DARPA and NASA to support robotics research. Many individuals from these teams went to work on Google’s Chauffeur Project, which eventually became Waymo, a leading AV company. However, based on interviews and analysis of competition archives, we found that other poorly-resourced teams who did not fare well during the DGCs—what we call “geek teams”—made significant component-based contributions. These innovations were surprising because geek teams often lacked robotics experience.

Over time, we realized that geek teams were learning about robotics not through partnerships with other universities or companies, but instead by reading technical publications and engaging in prolonged trial and error prototyping. In the process, many geek teams generated important new technologies and eventually established companies to commercialize their inventions. Especially important was their application of unique technical capabilities to robotics, such as when teams with experience in sonar created new types of ultrasonic sensors for the AV architecture, just as dozens of other geek teams created new components. And while the race vehicles of most geek teams functioned poorly, their work nonetheless primed them to quickly recognize and understand the technical accomplishments of other geek teams during DGC competition events. In other words, the work of building a robot and making unique component-based contributions to a shared robotics architecture helped create a shared sense of belonging—a collective identity—that provided a basis for the formation of a new AV industry.  

Through our research, we have therefore contributed to society’s understanding of the value of federal research and development investments, how new industries emerge, and the role of cognitive and emotional factors therein. In particular, we highlight the important role of individuals who may not possess disciplinary (in our case, robotics) knowledge but who nonetheless bring unique perspectives and contributions to fields otherwise led by academic research institutions. Our research therefore holds important lessons for science and innovation policy, as well as the government’s role in the formation of new technology-based industries.


Last Modified: 12/30/2023
Modified by: Christopher S Hayter
